posts.name: Krishiv
posts.cooked:
Hello!

This year my team has a variable-angle elevator, and we were wondering how teams improved the stability of a mechanism like this. We were thinking of using a constant force spring in order to prevent it from jumping back and forth from jolts when driving

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Is the movement mostly from slop (backlash), flex in the system, or the motor being overpowered ?

posts.name: Krishiv
posts.cooked: its from backlashâ€¦ we are using webbing to move it up and allowing gravity to pull it down. We are trying to make it smootherâ€¦ I can post a picture if that helps !

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: And what range of motion needs to be covered? 90degrees?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Yes, a constant force spring or two pulling down will help stabilize it.  You should be able to get away with a pretty strong one.  You DO need to watch that the spring doesnâ€™t pull your winch down before the match starts!  If you had a way to add some damping to the spring that could help further.  Either draggy spool or a rubber suspended spool or end mount might help too.  Or some felt pads pressed against the spring itself.  Maybe make the spring slide over a felt covered curve?  I think just getting the hold-down in place will help quite a bit.  Probably 80% of the value right there!

You should add some shrouding to keep the strap from jumping off your drum; that would be catastrophic!

posts.name: Krishiv
posts.cooked: so should we have a spring that is going up and the other pulling down?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: No, all down fighting your winch.

posts.name: Brandon Liatys
posts.cooked: Weâ€™ve found that using vex components for a mechanism like this introduces a ton of slop from their tolerances on the hubs and gears, so if that is how your mechanism is attached I would get some shim stock and shim whatever is attached to the shaft it rotates on. Also helps to make sure your belt/chain/whatever is spinning this is properly tensioned.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
